title-group.article-title: Pressure and oxygen debt on bypass – potential quality markers of perfusion?

contrib-group.aff: Liverpool Heart and Chest Hospital, Liverpool, UK

author-notes.corresp: Michael Poullis,The Cardiothoracic Centre,Thomas Drive, Liverpool, L14 3PE, UK Email: Mike.Poullis@lhch.nhs.uk

abstract.p: No markers of quality of perfusion pressure and oxygen delivery during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), to complement rewarming rate, maximum temperature on rewarming, lowest haematocrit, and blood glucose, exist. Using the electronic acquisition of blood pressure on bypass (JOCAP system), the percentage of time perfusion pressure was below 30, 40, 50, 60 and 70 mmHg, average deviance, confidence interval, median, mode, standard deviation, variance, and average, maximum and cumulative oxygen debt were calculated. Numerous different readouts of achievement of maintenance of constant pressure on bypass and oxygen debt are now easily achievable with perfusion electronic data management systems. Mean, median, and mode offer poor discrimination of pressure control during CPB. Percentage of time perfusion pressure was below 30, 40, 50, 60 and 70 mmHg, average deviance, confidence interval, and standard deviation all have discriminatory power, but need clinical correlation for their significance. A composite score involving non-pressure readouts (e.g. oxygen delivery, arterial and venous saturations, and flow rates) may need to be integrated into any perfusion quality marker. Assessment of adequacy of constant perfusion pressure and oxygen delivery may allow the scientific evaluation of pressure and oxygen delivery on bypass for patients to be compared accurately. Currently, in studies involving CPB, blood pressure targets are stated with no quantitative assessment of adequacy of achievement of these targets. Electronic data monitoring during cardiopulmonary bypass, when correlated with clinical outcome, may help to provide a marker of quality of perfusion pressure during CPB and may, indeed, allow patient-specific perfusion pressure strategies to be developed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Electronic data management during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) has the potential to unlock numerous unanswered questions that have lingered from the initial introduction of CPB.

Despite evidence-based perfusion guidelines1, the optimal pressure on bypass remains an unanswered question, hence, the lack of guidelines and consensus2,3. However, even a cursory read of the literature on studies investigating pressure on bypass provide no evidence of achievement of their blood pressure targets: “pressures were maintained about 60 mmHg during CPB”4-6. Was the pressure 61 or 81? Did it swing wildly between 61 and 81? Was it closer to 61 than 81 or vice versa?

Organ damage secondary to CPB is thought to originate from ischaemia reperfusion injury and or inflammation7. Ischaemia results from a deficiency in oxygen delivery. The recent identification of oxygen delivery below 272 ml/min/m2 and the development of renal failure post CPB has, potentially, opened up a new level of understanding for the importance of minimum haematocrit and oxygen delivery during CPB8. We speculated that an oxygen delivery rate below 272 ml/min/m2 is associated with the development of an oxygen debt and, via this, we introduce the concept of average, maximum, and cumulative oxygen debt.

Our aim is to develop the concept of markers of quality of perfusion pressure and oxygen delivery during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) to complement existing markers of perfusion quality – rewarming rate, maximum temperature on rewarming, lowest haematocrit, and blood glucose9. Matching the conditions of bypass as closely to the individual patient’s normal physiology as possible is true patient-directed bypass.

sec.title: Data Acquisition
sec.p: Using the electronic acquisition of blood pressure on bypass (JOCAP system, MAQUET GmbH & Co. KG, Rastatt, Germany) blood pressure traces were acquired for two typical CPB cases (Figures 1 and 2): case 1 had frequent boluses of a vasoconstrictor administered to maintain perfusion pressure during CPB; case 2 had no vasoconstrictor added, but the heart and CPB pipes were manipulated halfway through the CPB run. The anaesthetic technique was identical in the two cases.

caption.p: A highly variable blood pressure run on bypass for 208 minutes.
A relatively uniform blood pressure run on bypass for 66 minutes.

sec.title: Pressure on bypass
sec.p: The percentage of time the perfusion pressure was below 30, 40, 50, 60 or 70 mmHg (Figure 3), average deviance, confidence interval, median, mode, standard deviation, and variance were calculated (Table 1).

caption.p: Demonstration of how only periods of blood pressure below “cutoff” are used when calculating “percentage of time perfusion pressure was below cutoff”. Downward arrows indicate flow down.
The percentage of time perfusion pressure was below 30, 40, 50, 60 and 70 mmHg: average deviance, confidence interval, median, mode, standard deviation, and variance

sec.title: Oxygen delivery
sec.p: Oxygen delivery was calculated from the pump flow, haematocrit and arterial saturation as follows 10,11:

disp-quote.p: Sa02: Arterial haemoglobin oxygen saturation (decimal percent)

sec.p: It has been shown previously that patients need a minimum of 272 mL/min/m2 to reduce the incidence of renal dysfunction post CPB8. Instantaneous oxygen debt can be calculated from the difference. The average and cumulative were calculated as follows:

The average, maximum, and cumulative oxygen debt are shown in Table 2. The percentage of time O2 delivery was less than 50% (136 mL/min/m2), and 75% (204 mL/min/m2) were arbitrarily chosen for demonstration purposes.

caption.p: Average, maximum, and cumulative oxygen debt levels.

tr.td: Percentage of time O2 delivery was less than:

sec.title: Software and Statistics
sec.p: Microsoft Excel was utilised with the standard mathematical functions add-on. Mathematical functions utilised are detailed in Appendix 1 to allow easy replication.
Statistical significance was deliberately not calculated as the clinical significance of our concepts analysis is currently unknown.

sec.title: Data acquisition
sec.p: It can be seen that Figures 1 and 2 have very different CPB blood pressure profiles. In Figure 1, the perfusion pressure is highly variable and the time spent on bypass was 208 minutes. In Figure 2, the perfusion pressure was remarkably constant, with a bypass time of 66 minutes. These cases were picked to contrast the statistical tests utilised as they are visibly so different with respect to perfusion pressure.

sec.title: Pressure on bypass
sec.p: Table 1 demonstrates very little difference in the mean, median and mode for perfusion pressure variation during CPB. The variance would seem to have the most discrimination with regard to blood pressure variability, but this needs to be correlated with risk adjusted clinical outcomes.

sec.title: Oxygen delivery
sec.p: Table 2 demonstrates the average, maximum, and cumulative oxygen debt levels for the two on-pump cases. It can be seen that the average, the maximum and the cumulative oxygen debt can easily discriminate between a “smooth” bypass run and a more “variable” one, with regard to oxygen delivery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Numerous different readouts of achievement of maintenance of constant pressure on bypass and oxygen delivery are now easily achievable with perfusion electronic data management systems12. Mean, median and mode are poor at differentiating good and bad blood pressure management during CPB.

Assessment of adequacy of constant perfusion pressure and oxygen delivery may allow the scientific evaluation of pressure and oxygen delivery on bypass for patients to be compared accurately. Currently, in studies involving CPB, blood pressure targets are stated with no quantitative assessment of adequacy of achievement of these targets. Electronic data monitoring during cardiopulmonary bypass, when correlated with clinical outcome, may help to provide a marker of quality of perfusion pressure during CPB13 and may, indeed, allow patient-specific perfusion pressure strategies to be developed.

Time on bypass is an independent risk factor for developing organ ischaemia post cardiac surgery. It should be noted that mean, median, mode, standard deviation, variance, average deviance, confidence interval, percentage of time that the blood pressure is less than 30, 40, 50 or 60mmHg, and maximum oxygen debt are all independent of length of bypass. Cumulative oxygen debt is the only factor that is affected by duration of bypass and degrees of relative hypoperfusion. Cumulative and maximum oxygen debt may both be significant factors predicting organ ischaemia, but this remains speculation until clinical correlative studies are performed.

In the future, a composite score involving non-pressure readouts (e.g. oxygen delivery, arterial and venous saturations, and flow rates) may need to be integrated into any perfusion pressure quality marker as perfusion pressure alone reveals nothing about capillary bed oxygenation and perfusion.
We define the term “oxygen debt cutoff level” to try and impress the importance of a potential target being of clinical relevance as opposed to statistical significance.

Oxygen debt or, more correctly, sub-optimal perfusion may help to tease out subtle causes of organ dysfunction such as occurs with the brain14. Having the blood pressure less than 40 mmHg for only 2% of the time on CPB, our case 1, equated to a period of 4 minutes. If this is all in a continuous time frame, compared to multiple well spaced out shorter periods, then the chance of cerebral injury must be much higher, due to the brain’s poor ability to sustain hypoxic insults, hence, the use of the terms maximum and cumulative O2 debt. This concept is represented diagrammatically in Figure 4.

caption.p: Oxygen debt-derived variables during CPB. Downward arrows indicate flow down. It can be seen that the longer the duration of reduced flow and the lower the flow is decreased to, the more oxygen debt that is incurred. Resumption of normal flow helps repay this oxygen debt. If periods of flow reduction are widely spaced, the oxygen debt can be repaid. However, short periods of reduced flow which, individually, are not highly significant, that are closely spaced, do not allow this to occur, incurring an oxygen debt.

sec.p: Potentially, the highest ischaemic load period of bypass is at the end as the surgeon may ask for repeated episodes of “flow down” to do the proximal anastomoses and / or control bleeding points. If these “flow down” periods are short, but frequent, not allowing any incurred oxygen debt to be repaid, then end-organ ischaemia may result.

The percentage of time O2 delivery was less than 50% or 75% was arbitrarily chosen to demonstrate the point, but a study with clinical outcomes is needed before drawing any firm conclusions as to a definitive cutoff.

As we have so far failed to define what CPB perfusion pressure should be utilised clinically2,3, trying to score consistency of pressure on bypass may seem premature; however, with the availability of using electronic data management systems, studies can be analysed critically with regard to their adequacy of achieving a perfusion pressure target, so their conclusions can be interpreted correctly.

sec.title: Limitations and future work
sec.p: We have presented only concepts and further clinically related work that links with patient morbidity and mortality is needed. We have focused on the period of CPB and not investigated patient risk factors before or after CPB. The assessment of a patient’s preoperative blood pressure may help elucidate the “correct pressure” for CPB15 as it is likely that one pressure fits all is clinically wrong and “patient-directed bypass” may be the way forward16.

caption.p: Excel functions and their descriptions utilised for calculations

tr.td: The median is the number in the middle of a set of numbers; that is, half the numbers have values that are greater than the median and half have values that are less.
Returns the most frequently occurring or repetitive value in an array or range of data.
A measure of how widely values are dispersed from the average value (the mean).
Estimates variance based on a sample.
A measure of the variability in a data set (average of the absolute deviations of data points from their mean).
A range on either side of a sample mean.
